text.0:
A video claiming to show Kenya’s President Uhuru Kenyatta commenting on the 35-year rule of Uganda’s President Yoweri Museveni has been taken out of context and is :cross_mark: FALSE.

:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: President Kenyatta made the remarks before he was elected: https://t.co/wF9k0kmAk5
text.1:
:police_car_light: HOAX: A Twitter account impersonating MP Millie Odhiambo with a post calling for a revisit of the symbolic “handshake” between Raila Odinga and Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta is fake.

:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: The legislator has dismissed the account as parody: https://t.co/eRwU1Xojhv
text.2:
A Facebook post claiming that US President Donald Trump has announced permanent e-visas for Kenyan citizens is :cross_mark: FALSE.

:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: Kenya's embassy in the US has dismissed the claim on its official website and Facebook account: https://t.co/TESvJgQWga
text.3:
A Facebook post with a screenshot of an article claiming the senator of Kenya's Baringo County, Gideon Moi, has opened up about his life in poverty is SATIRE.

:performing_arts: The article in the screenshot was originally published by PostaMate, a satirical website: https://t.co/KJo6DDKDzp
text.4:
A Facebook post with an image of tweets claiming a poll predicted John Magufuli will win Tanzania's general election by 82% is MISLEADING.

:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: The tweet is from an account that does not exist, and research firm Rhemasoft has denied conducting such a poll: https://t.co/7WsBTMusvC
text.5:
:police_car_light: HOAX: A poster shared on Facebook claiming that Kenya's National Youth Service (NYS) is offering free courses for servicemen and women is fake.

The NYS has dismissed the poster and says it is a scam: https://t.co/COfJzH8zSM
